message_1: In how many ways can you arrange a sequence of 6 left and 6 right turns (starting and ending with a left turn), such that the sequence never goes below the x-axis (i.e., the number of right turns never exceed the number of left turns)?
message_2:
This problem can be solved using the Catalan numbers. The nth Catalan number is given by the formula:

C(n) = (1/(n+1)) * (2n! / (n! * n!))

In this case, we have 6 left turns and 6 right turns, so n = 6. Plugging this into the formula, we get:

C(6) = (1/(6+1)) * (12! / (6! * 6!))

C(6) = (1/7) * (479001600 / (720 * 720))

C(6) = (1/7) * (665280)

C(6) = 132256

So there are 132,256 ways to arrange a sequence of 6 left and 6 right turns such that the sequence never goes below the x-axis.
